Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Novel solar cells using silicon nanocrystals synthesized in an atmospheric pressure plasma

POR.DRECONTENT:
Solar cells represent the most promising technological route to a clean energy future, and their widespread implementation depends on the development of new materials that enable high-efficiency energy conversion at low cost. Silicon nanocrystals are one such material, and offer both new scientific (quantum confinement, multiple exciton generation) and technological (printable films) advantages over existing materials. Current research focuses on the synthesis, characterization, and control of nanocrystals.

Under NSF EAPSI award 1014982, I joined the Okazaki and Nozaki laboratory at the Tokyo Institute of Technology in Tokyo, Japan for ten weeks. The laboratory has a history in atmospheric plasma research, and such plasmas provide a promising approach to nanocrystal synthesis. Our research sought to produce silicon nanocrystals at atmospheric pressure via the decomposition of silicon tetrachloride vapor and hydrogen gas, and characterize the nanocrystals’ potential for use in future solar cells. We successfully synthesized silicon nanocrystals with diameters of approximately 3 nm (see electron micrograph) in powder form. Near-instant oxidation of the nanocrystals upon air exposure was a persistent problem—a problem that must be addressed before solar cell fabrication since the oxide surface layer inhibits charge carrier transport. Future research in the Okazaki and Nozaki laboratory must strive to prevent oxidation either by altering the as-synthesized nanocrystal surface chemistry (e.g., hydrogen termination is known to resist oxidation), or by working in inert atmospheres. Subsequently, the formation of films of nanocrystals—and solar cells based on these films—may be addressed.
